author: cian riordan
content: Newbie is crushing out the gate

author: cian riordan
content: Agreed -- be critical of everything. Be critical of things that are expensive for the sake of being expensive. Things that are just  instagram ads shilling to newbies. Critical of  Greg Wells pandering to whatever his base is. But recommending a 4k converter based on 'audible conversion quality' isn't helpful if the consumer doesn't have a million other ducks in a row first -- room treatment, adequate monitoring, proper gainstaging, etc. Jon has that figured out, so it makes sense for him. But when people come into a forum with questionable knowledge and background in music production asking what's the best converter, I think it's fair to ask some prying questions before just making blanket recommendations on what one person heard or not. I have plenty of semi-OK stuff that still gets used on the regular, and plenty of expensive gear that I would happily toss out of my workflow. They're all just tools. And whether its bougie DW Fearn or a black-friday Acustica plugin, , if it works for your workflow and gets you results you're happy with, then its worth whatever money you're willing to pay for it.

author: oaklandmatt
content: This is why we have a newbie question channel! ❤️

author: montrose recording
content:
im here to answer some newbie questions.  

my 2 cents though after doing this gig for more than half my life is that there arnt big rights and wrongs and no one silver bullet will solve any problem.  ive probably made all the mistakes - ive had huge swings in workflow and between  engineer to artist to mixer.   few things fatigue me more than folks discussing the ‘correct and only way’ to do something because i truly believe there are many many correct ways to solve a problem in music production

btw i think ive learned far more from observation than questioning fwiw

that being said - fire away

author: cian riordan
content: Who needs AI when you have Discord-Newbie-Questions-GPT

author: Adam Thein
content: I’d also say this doesn’t have to be an all in thing - challenge yourself to keep the 40 hour job and work on music for 15-20 hours a week on top of that.  In reality if you are just starting as a freelance engineer or if you are trying to make your own music career as an artist you will be often working 50, 60+ hours per week

author: NoahNeedleman
content: We’re not having this convo again, and especially not in Newbie Channel

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Maybe this is a hot take, but I believe everyone is actually self-taught. We each have unique learning styles- some are better with visual examples, some auditory, some complete fucking animals read the manual, 
Some like no examples at all and just want to experiment. 

Modern music making is a playground, and doing things wrong often engenders creativity.   Technique is teachable, but artistry is only cultivated. 

Curiosity and tenacity are the only skills required. Everything else is a google search away.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Hey @everyone! We added a channel for newbie/ beginner/ "dumb" questions. This whole community is about helping each other, so even if you don't have any newbie questions to ask, please check this channel to help answer questions too!

questions can be about anything! music making, how discord works, or anything else the community can help with.

author: cian riordan
content: I think starting out with a modern compressor with all the parameters available to you will be more helpful in learning the concept. That way you can really understand the idea of a threshold, different attack/release combinations, and and compression ratios. Once you can start to understand what you're hearing, then you can apply that to other compressors that might have more fixed variables (LA2a, etc). I've always found overdoing it when you're first getting the settings will help you understand whats going on.

author: spectrummasters
content: Good luck with it all 🙏🏼. Before any questions of my own when I’m brand new to a situation where I don’t have the expertise …..I tend to try and get as much of a read as I can of how the experts want me to learn ……ie . Just be quiet and watch and learn for a while ? or immediately fill the air with a bunch of questions . I find that often I need to be taught for a while before I even can know what questions I have . Sorry if that’s not a list of questions …..but I’d go for “listening to everything everyone’s saying “ as answering the questions I didn’t know to ask yet . Specific questions come as@my knowledge base builds and I reflect .

author: Adam Thein
content:
One other thing about paid plugins from large companies - you can count on Waves or UAD, Soundtoys, Izotope all updating their tools on newer OS.  Some (definitely not all) free plugs are made by people starting out in developing plugins and they might move on to other things.

Actually in the middle of this situation now where a single dev plugin was used on a track and I can’t even buy the license anymore.

author: Adam Thein
content: It's a little tough - if you are learning subtractive synthesis from the beginning a synth without preset recall can be really helpful because what you see on the knobs is what you hear.  But once you move beyond beginner the practicality of being able to store your patches makes the utility way better for live performance or moving quickly in a production

author: Slow Hand
content: Modulars are great and boatloads of fun, but I wouldn't recommend them to anyone who is just starting out because they're expensive, overwhelming, and an absolute rabbit hole.

author: spectrummasters
content: This popped up on my YT T/L yesterday . I had a Quick Look and first impression was : I don’t think I’ve seen anything as thorough with regard to the whole process of a record as this . Jacquire King going into great detail with a video series taking a song from preproduction , through recording , through editing to mixing . It is the same song throughout with separate long form videos for each stage of the process . It’s also as much about the why as the what . If you’re a newbie this video series might be a fun way to watch someone working

author: mario dones
content: After spending years studying from afar, I buckled down and started mixing at the end of last year. LWMR really helped everything click for me. I used to be an artist, so I have years and years of recording experience, and doing rough mixes for myself and the homies, but I’m very new to this side of things. I was lurking around on here and I see that it’s common when starting out that doing free mixes can easily turn into doing much more. I only have 2 real “clients” right now but I’m mixing, producing, writing, recording… I love it, don’t get me wrong. The more I can help, the better. I guess I’m just having trouble navigating this space. Going deep with these 2 artists, I’m having a hard time building a portfolio, which is messing with my confidence. Specially with mixing. I can get thumbs up from the people I’m working with, my mentor (my old engineer), but without audience interaction I don’t know what to do with that. I’d like to take on more work, but I only have 1 mix out. Hopefully an EP a couple more mixes by the end of next month. I feel weird shopping myself with no portfolio, free work or not. I don’t know where I stand, where to focus my energy and everything just feels like it’s on slow-drip. Any advice?

author: oaklandmatt
content: "buyouts" def exist. Ghost producers, large songwriting fees to give away publishing, etc. Not crediting you as a mixer seems like a bad precedent to set though. Hard to say. Whenever you accept something like, you're devaluing your work and credibility in the long run (with this client and also with yourself). So it's hard to know the right answer, but I rarely do this, even when I was starting out. Just a bad precedent.

author: peterlabberton
content: I’m sure you’ve read this or could find it with a quick google search, but starting with the first reflection points would be my first step. Side walls next to the listening position and ceiling above. Then probably behind the listening position and perhaps behind the speakers. If you have anything to use as a bass trap, I’d recommend using something like fuzzmeasure to shoot the room and experiment with placing that stuff in different places. You’ll be able to see peaks and valleys moving around in the low end, assuming what you’re using is actually effective at sucking up bass. There are people with much more knowledge than me, but that’s where I’d start!

author: peterlabberton
content: Yes, but… I think it’s worth avoiding burning money if there’s truly no measurable or practical difference—and if you’re just starting out and you’ve got no money to burn! A fun and inspiring synth could make 100x more music than an overhyped converter!

author: ehutton21
content:
I’m not sure if this is a newbie question or not, but I’ll throw it here anyways and see what happens (I hope it helps newbies too). I’m already somewhat aware of the answers I may get, but who knows. Sorry if this is long, I’m bad at short form.

Context: I have been producing music in sincerity for maybe 3 years now, been a hobby since like 16. I’ve started to engineer out of necessity for my individual artistry, but one thing led to the next and I gained a fair bit of skill at it (or so I’ve been told, I’m still pretty insecure, honestly even being around all the really knowledge people on here makes my panic disorder go 📈). I’ve gotten an internship at a studio as a runner and a session assistant down here (it’s not paid but it’s not exactly unpaid), and I truly have learned a lot (I learn something new on the daily I swear), but I’ve yet to have any true guidance from an established figure yet (which very well may never happen), which I know isn’t necessary, but it absolutely makes me question my own abilities/career decisions despite what happens with my freelance work and I’m curious to know if this is like normal/how other people cope. 

Like, I’ve gotten a somewhat okay share of people who pay for my work as an engineer/producer/writer, but the “do you really know what you’re doing” doubt doesn’t fade easily—even when I’ve been paid by people on like label level budgets, I’m never really registering that success. I’ve had cool moments and landed spotify placements as a mixer for artists, and there’s this part of me that’s still somewhat ashamed that I do a lot more work for free than I care to admit. 

Maybe it’s the comments on the old episodes that has me spooked (Jon on #61 re: “not everyone can be a mixer”), but is this like just me or do even some of the really wicked smart people here still feel that—and if so, how do you guys handle the it?

author: cy (sigh)
content:
facts.

started out doing so  much metal /banda/folk/infie stuff for free when i was starting out ( a lot of school contacts) and didn't  ask for credit but my first 3 paying clients were all session musicians in those free gigs. 

word of mouth and putting in thw time/work really pays off 
 though it can def be frustrating. even when ppl think you're "expensive" when you start charging they'll see the value in your work once they try someone who's cheaper "juat cause". that consistency is everything and showing them you are doing everything for the song/project can be more important than the final song itself

author: Slow Hand
content:
My most-used commands are:

Cmd + Opt + B: Open/close browser.
Cmd + Opt + L: Open/close bottom track window.
Shift + Tab: Toggle between *Instrument View* and *Clip View* in the bottom track window.

I'm a habitual window toggler. If I'm not using the window it gets hidden immediately. I probably wouldn't mention it to a newbie, but it's probably a nice reminder for more seasoned users.

author: BoozleBAM
content: Please tell me if this should be in Newbie Questions or Recording talk - I hate to misplace stuff. Anyway. I have a question about recording guitars: I have a bunch of songs that fluctuate a lot dynamically. Live, I use three or four clean boosts to drive my amp into different levels of distortion (jcm 800). The last time I did a record, I just did it as though i was playing live - just hitting the boosts along with the click when the song went into the different sections. It worked fine, but I've had many working engineers tell me that's NOT the way to do it. Rather, I should have recorded each section that has a different level of distortion/ intensity on its own, so that way I can have more control over the mix and end up with cleaner transitions, potentially... I'm just curious how people here may have handled such a thing. Not that it's important, probably, but I'll add that I don't use any volume or tone controls on my guitars - just humbucker straight to jack. I control all the dynamics with my pedals and strumming hand. Thanks.

author: Bryan DiMaio
